prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established that grouping long-term point trajectories yields object-level motion segments, directly motivating the paper’s choice to supervise segmentation with trajectories rather than instantaneous flow.

prior_works.title: Segmentation of Moving Objects by Long-Term Video Analysis
prior_works.authors: Peter Ochs; Jitendra Malik; Thomas Brox
prior_works.role: Robust trajectory clustering for motion grouping
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed how affinities over extended trajectories can reliably partition objects, informing the paper’s emphasis on nonparametric, long-horizon motion cues as supervision.

prior_works.title: A Multibody Factorization Method for Motion Segmentation
prior_works.role: Foundational low-rank subspace model of trajectories
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided the theoretical basis that trajectories from a rigid object lie in a low-dimensional subspace, underpinning the paper’s low-rank grouping objective.

prior_works.title: Sparse Subspace Clustering: Algorithm, Theory, and Applications
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Inspired the idea that each trajectory can be expressed as a combination of others from the same subspace, directly reflected in the paper’s self-expressive/low-rank loss for grouping tracks.

prior_works.title: Robust Subspace Segmentation by Low-Rank Representation
prior_works.authors: Guangcan Liu; Zhouchen Lin; Yong Yu
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Motivated enforcing low-rank structure to separate multiple subspaces, which the paper adapts to organize point trajectories into object-consistent groups.

prior_works.title: Improved Dense Trajectories
prior_works.role: Practical extraction of dense long-term point tracks
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Popularized reliable dense trajectory extraction in videos, a practical prerequisite for using trajectories as supervision in learning-based segmentation.

prior_works.title: Learning Motion Patterns for Video Object Segmentation
prior_works.authors: Pavel Tokmakov; Karteek Alahari; Cordelia Schmid
prior_works.role: Deep VOS from optical-flow motion cues
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated training segmentation networks from motion (instantaneous flow) cues, providing the immediate baseline that this paper extends to long-term trajectory supervision.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core contribution—training a segmentation network from long-term point trajectories using a subspace-inspired, low-rank grouping loss—sits at the intersection of classical motion segmentation and subspace clustering theory. Early motion segmentation works by Brox and Malik, and later Ochs, Malik, and Brox, established that aggregating long-horizon point trajectories is a powerful way to realize the Gestalt principle of common fate, achieving object-level grouping beyond what instantaneous optical flow affords. Parallel to this, multibody factorization by Costeira and Kanade provided the foundational insight that trajectories from a rigid object lie in a low-dimensional subspace. Modern subspace clustering formulations—especially Sparse Subspace Clustering (SSC) and Low-Rank Representation (LRR)—operationalized this principle through self-expressiveness and low-rank objectives that partition data into multiple subspaces.

Practically, the widespread use of dense, long-duration tracks popularized by Improved Dense Trajectories made trajectories an accessible signal for downstream learning. In deep video object segmentation, Tokmakov et al. showed that motion-based supervision from optical flow can train segmentation networks, but is fundamentally limited by instantaneous cues. The present work synthesizes these streams: it replaces flow-only supervision with long-term trajectories and imports subspace clustering’s self-expressiveness/low-rank priors to define a differentiable loss that encourages object-consistent grouping of tracks. This bridges classical trajectory-based motion segmentation and modern deep VOS, delivering a learning framework that captures complex, long-range motion patterns without imposing brittle parametric motion models.
